awd_titl_txt: NSF-BSF: Elementary Particle Physics with ATLAS
awd_abstract_narration:
This award will provide support for the NYU group working on the ATLAS experiment at the Large Hadron Collider (LHC) at CERN, a particle physics laboratory in Geneva, Switzerland. The LHC machine and ATLAS, a large particle detector facility, were built as basic science tools using funds from NSF and other agencies around the world. One of their primary objectives was to find the Higgs Boson, the last particle in the historically successful "Standard Model" (SM) that accounts for so much of the existence of, and forces between, known particles forming the matter in the universe. This effort has been successful. The next step in the experiments is to look for evidence for physics Beyond the Standard Model (BSM) that might, for instance, account for the presence of the mysterious "Dark Matter" that makes up so much of the mass of the universe. The LHC is currently in the midst of Run 2, at almost twice the energy explored earlier and with significantly increased event samples. It is possible that evidence for BSM physics could emerge at this higher energy and with the higher event statistics from the current run and by means of further upgrades of the LHC and ATLAS to follow.

Analytically, the NYU group will be studying Higgs decays, searching for evidence of supersymmetry and exotic new states of matter through several approaches, including the reaction process known as Vector Boson Fusion, and will be developing novel approaches to the reconstruction and study of high energy Jets.  NYU will partner with the Weizmann Institute of Science through support from the US-Israel Binational Science Foundation program to search for the decays of Higgs boson decays to charm quark pairs, through heavy flavor tagging.   Here the joint NYU-Weizmann effort will exploit advanced machine learning techniques to identify and select such challenging final states in Higgs decay. 

Technical projects include improvements and refinements of the ATLAS trigger for missing energy, a key variable in the searches for new physics, and track triggering, an essential technique for dealing with reconstruction of events in very high rate collisions, which are endemic at the LHC.  The group also helps to lead a smaller experimental effort called milliQan, whose objective is to search for fractionally charged particles that might be produced at the LHC.

The NYU group's broader impacts efforts are extensive.  For general audiences, the NYU exhibit on the LHC is estimated to reach large numbers of school-age children, and the "Higgs Hunters" project has engaged users from a variety of age groups in significant numbers.  For secondary school educators, workshops are also planned at NYU to familiarize and educate teachers with some of the state of the art tools used in the particle physics domain, to provide them with background to bring new knowledge to the classroom.  Additionally, the analytical projects of the group, which include statistical applications, machine learning, and analysis preservation tools and techniques, can be extended to fields outside of physics, and young researchers supported under this program will have training in such innovative and cross-cutting techniques.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This grant supported our NYU group's research into fundamental particle physics at the Large Hadron Collider (LHC) located at CERN. We work on the ATLAS and milliQan experiments at the LHC. 

The Standard Model (SM) of particle physics is very successful at explaining most of the known properties of particles and their interactions.  Its verified predictions include the existence of the Higgs particle, discovered by the ATLAS and CMS experiments in 2012. Theories beyond the standard model (BSM) predict new particles or forces to address questions left open by the SM.  The  large number of high energy proton-protons collisions measured at the LHC allow high-sensitivity studies to test for signs of deviation from the SM which would point to new physics. 

Our group used ATLAS data from LHC Run 2 (2015-2018) to test the SM and to search for evidence of BSM physics.  We have developed new statistical methods which are more sensitive to signs of new physics and more accurate in determining the likelihood of their occurence.  New, more sensitive methods have made possible studies which would otherwise be intractable. We have also developed technologies that allow preservation analyses for later reuse. This aids in reinterpreting searches to test new BSM theories and streamlines the onboarding of new researchers into the LHC experiments. 

The statistical tools we have developed have found a wide variety of applications outside of particle physics. The NYU group has established strong connections with the community developing modern data science and machine learning techniques, and is widely recognized in this space. 

Expected deviations from the SM due to BSM effects are subtle, so testing them with the ATLAS experiment requires measuring a large number (on the order of a million billion) LHC proton-proton interactions, culling a manageable number of these (about one in a hundred thousand) to be recorded for study using a multi-level trigger system. Our group has studied and helped improve the efficiency of the ATLAS "MET trigger,"  which is used to look for SM and BSM particles that escape the detector without interacting. 

Interpretation of measurements requires understanding what would be expected from the SM alone and what would change according to BSM theories.  Because of the complexity of the  particle collision process and the particle-detector interactions which give rise to the measurements, computer simulations are required to determine what is expected. Our group contributed to  the development of the ATLAS simulation, focusing on the effects of the large number of proton-proton interactions that occur when two LHC proton bunces collide.

To improve the sensitivity of measurements, the planned HL-LHC upgrade will result in a factor of about 10 increase in the rate of proton-proton interactions.  This requires upgrading a number of the components of the ATLAS detector.  Our group worked on the electronics upgrade for the ATLAS calorimeter, which measures the energy of particles produced in the interaction.

Our group has been a leader in the milliQan experiment, which searches for particles with electric charge a small fraction of that of the electron. In this grant period we have participated in development, construction and running of a 1% size detector prototype which was installed in a tunnel above the CMS LHC cavern and recorded data during LHC Run 2, and began installation of larger detectors for LHC Run 3.

The collaborative nature of our work, involving oral and written presentations to international groups, and the techniques we use to study large data sets and simulate complicated systems provide an excellent training ground for our students and postdoctoral researchers. We have also brought the excitement of the field and taught about the tools we use to K-12 educators. In collaboration with Brookhaven National Laboratory and the National Museum of Mathematics (MoMAth) we have developed and held workshops for teachers on statistical methods with the ATLAS trigger as a starting point which then lead to a broader discussion of how statistics can be used or misused in deriving conclusions based on data. Participating teachers then developed lesson plans to bring these ideas to their classrooms. These plans were shared with a broader community of teachers in MoMath Zoom events.
